column4: Drake2k: Thanks for the update too. I'm going to try and install it now too.
I also like to repeat the word "too"
!virtualbox | rallias
Rallias: Yes, you can try dual booting.
!dual boot | rallias
u there?
how do i tell my computer to permanently run the cpu at 2GHZ USERSPACE from boot even when running battery?
Good question and i'm just not sure. I know you can add an applet on the taskbar for setting CPU throttling/usage.
I thought the applet on the taskbar would lock the frequency.
not for amd chips.
http://ubuntuforums.org/archive/index.php/t-904748.html Might be soe use.
at least not the RM-70
RM stands for "remove" - used improperly you can delete all sorts of files and folders.
so like s*do rm <directory>
It's pretty useful too, though. (please do NOT issue the following command) rm -rf / will remove forceably your entire root directory, effectively meaning you'll need to do a full reinstall.
i dont feel like deleting my root directory, but what's the "-rf" switch for?
so if a process or kernel is using anything it tells it to f**k off and it deletes it anyway?
when ubuntu's appearance control app loads the little thumbnails of each theme, does it get them from /usr/share/themes?
I'm actually not too sure. I think it does take it from one of the configuration files in the folder.
I'm not sure why that is. Maybe you need to add them to a .themes folder in your home directory?
what if i want them availible to all users? im the only one on this computer, but this is somethign ill remember. i have anotehr computer with multiple users.

Normally themes are packaged and you install them through the "Appearance" window, where they're then copied into the right directory. I think it might just be the home directory, though.  Sometimes themes don't appear if they're not properly made, e.g. some of the description files are missing. I think that  file might be the "gtkrc" file
